claim: A 38-year-old imprisoned man is brought to the physician after going on a hunger strike for 36 hours. During this time, he has only had two cups of water. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes. His serum glucose concentration is 70 mg/dL. Which of the following enzymes contributes most to maintaining a normal serum glucose level in this patient? : Hydroxymethylglutaryl-CoA lyase

supporting.text: Hydroxymethylglutaryl-CoA lyase plays a critical role in ketone body synthesis, which provides an alternative energy source during fasting, indirectly supporting glucose homeostasis.

attacks.text: Hydroxymethylglutaryl-CoA lyase plays a critical role in ketone body synthesis, which provides an alternative energy source during fasting, indirectly supporting glucose homeostasis.
Ketone body synthesis alone cannot fully compensate for glucose depletion, especially in the brain, which relies primarily on glucose during short-term fasting.
Hydroxymethylglutaryl-CoA lyase is more relevant in prolonged fasting (days), not in the early phase (36 hours) where glycogenolysis is the dominant glucose source.
Even in short-term fasting, ketone bodies begin to rise and provide partial energy for peripheral tissues, sparing glucose for the brain.
Glycogen stores may already be depleted in this patient due to stress or prior malnutrition, making ketogenesis critical even at 36 hours.
The brain's glucose requirement is absolute in the first 48 hours, and ketone bodies cannot meet this demand until adaptation occurs.
Clinical evidence of dry mucous membranes suggests severe dehydration, which likely impaired glycogenolysis more than ketogenesis.
